exercises.question: The committee recommended that the proposal ___ further before a final decision is made.
exercises.answer: be scrutinized
exercises.hint: Formal Subjunctive: 'recommend that + subject + base form'
exercises.example_sentence: The committee recommended that the proposal be scrutinized further.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses a relative pronoun to refer back to a whole clause?
options: The company doubled its profits in a year, which was completely unexpected.
The company doubled its profits in a year, what was completely unexpected.
The company doubled its profits in a year, that was completely unexpected.
exercises.answer: The company doubled its profits in a year, which was completely unexpected.
exercises.hint: Use 'which' (preceded by a comma) to refer to the entire preceding idea
exercises.example_sentence: The company doubled its profits in a year, which was completely unexpected.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using a formal time relative.
exercises.answer: The contract expires in June at which point negotiations will resume
exercises.example_sentence: The contract expires in June, at which point negotiations will resume.

exercises.question: Match the subjunctive triggers with their following clauses.

pairs.right: he take a leave of absence

exercises.hint: Subjunctive uses the base form of the verb
exercises.example_sentence: It is essential that everyone be present for the announcement.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal demand: 'It is imperative that the security protocols be strictly followed.'
exercises.answer: It is imperative that the security protocols be strictly followed.
exercises.example_sentence: It is imperative that the security protocols be strictly followed.

exercises.question: There were three candidates for the position, all ___ whom were highly qualified.
exercises.answer: of
exercises.example_sentence: There were three candidates for the position, all of whom were highly qualified.

exercises.question: Identify the correct formal way to describe a reason for something.
options: The reason for which he left remains a mystery.
The reason because he left remains a mystery.
The reason why that he left remains a mystery.
exercises.answer: The reason for which he left remains a mystery.
exercises.example_sentence: The reason for which he left remains a mystery.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a past occurrence.
exercises.answer: Seldom has the industry seen such rapid technological advancement
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom has the industry seen such rapid technological advancement.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level verbs to their formal synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: We must take steps to rectify the error immediately.

exercises.question: Pronounce the complex relative clause: 'The situation, the cause of which is unknown, is being monitored.'
exercises.answer: The situation, the cause of which is unknown, is being monitored.
exercises.hint: Pause slightly before and after the commas
exercises.example_sentence: The situation, the cause of which is unknown, is being monitored.

exercises.question: The board insisted that the CEO ___ a formal apology for the oversight.
exercises.answer: issue
exercises.example_sentence: The board insisted that the CEO issue a formal apology.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'notwithstanding' as a preposition?
options: Notwithstanding the high costs, the project was approved.
Notwithstanding that high costs, the project was approved.
Notwithstanding of the high costs, the project was approved.
exercises.answer: Notwithstanding the high costs, the project was approved.
exercises.example_sentence: Notwithstanding the high costs, the project was approved.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a potential scenario.
exercises.answer: Should you wish to cancel please notify us in writing
exercises.example_sentence: Should you wish to cancel, please notify us in writing.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level idioms to their formal descriptions.
exercises.example_sentence: Further changes to the tax system are in the offing.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic result: 'Such was the success of the campaign that revenue tripled.'
exercises.answer: Such was the success of the campaign that revenue tripled.
exercises.example_sentence: Such was the success of the campaign that revenue tripled.

exercises.question: The report highlights the way ___ technology is changing the workplace.
exercises.answer: in which
exercises.example_sentence: The report highlights the way in which technology is changing the workplace.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'no matter' with an adverb.
options: No matter how frequently he practices, he still makes mistakes.
No matter which frequent he practices, he still makes mistakes.
No matter what frequently he practices, he still makes mistakes.
exercises.answer: No matter how frequently he practices, he still makes mistakes.
exercises.example_sentence: No matter how frequently he practices, he still makes mistakes.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing a past hypothesis.
exercises.answer: Had they been aware of the risks they might have declined
exercises.example_sentence: Had they been aware of the risks, they might have declined.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words to their collocations.
exercises.example_sentence: The two issues are inextricably linked and cannot be solved separately.

exercises.question: Pronounce the transition: 'Conversely, many small businesses have thrived.'
exercises.answer: Conversely, many small businesses have thrived.
exercises.example_sentence: Conversely, many small businesses have thrived.

exercises.question: Since the party was so boring, we might as ___ have stayed at home.
exercises.answer: well
exercises.hint: Modal perfect: 'might as well have' (used to express that a different action would have been better)
exercises.example_sentence: Since the party was so boring, we might as well have stayed at home.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses a participle clause to replace a reason clause?
options: Not knowing the way, I had to ask for directions.
Not to know the way, I had to ask for directions.
Not known the way, I had to ask for directions.
exercises.answer: Not knowing the way, I had to ask for directions.
exercises.hint: Present participle (-ing) replaces 'Because I did not know...'
exercises.example_sentence: Not knowing the way, I had to ask for directions.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing a past possibility that didn't happen.
exercises.answer: The project could have been finished on time had we started earlier
exercises.hint: Combines modal perfect with conditional inversion
exercises.example_sentence: The project could have been finished on time had we started earlier.

exercises.question: Match the nouns with their required prepositions in C1 contexts.
exercises.example_sentence: His thirst for knowledge led him to pursue three degrees.

exercises.question: Pronounce the critical modal: 'You could at least have told me you were going to be late.'
exercises.answer: You could at least have told me you were going to be late.
exercises.example_sentence: You could at least have told me you were going to be late.

exercises.question: The company’s reputation is ___ stake if this deal falls through.
exercises.answer: at
exercises.example_sentence: The company’s reputation is at stake if this deal falls through.

exercises.question: Choose the correct structure for a 'perfect participle' clause.
options: Having completed the assignment, she went out for a walk.
Completed the assignment, she went out for a walk.
Having complete the assignment, she went out for a walk.
exercises.answer: Having completed the assignment, she went out for a walk.
exercises.hint: Having + past participle shows one action finished before another
exercises.example_sentence: Having completed the assignment, she went out for a walk.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a rare event.
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances should you divulge this information
exercises.hint: Negative inversion: Start with 'Under no circumstances'
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances should you divulge this information.

exercises.question: Match the formal verbs with their corresponding C1 objects.
exercises.example_sentence: The storm is expected to wreak havoc on the coastal towns.

exercises.question: Pronounce the complex condition: 'Were the circumstances different, I would certainly agree.'
exercises.answer: Were the circumstances different, I would certainly agree.
exercises.example_sentence: Were the circumstances different, I would certainly agree.

exercises.question: The results were disappointing, but ___ all probability, we will improve next year.
exercises.answer: in
exercises.example_sentence: In all probability, we will improve next year.

exercises.question: Identify the correct preposition for expressing a reason for a state.
options: He was overcome with emotion when he heard the news.
He was overcome by emotion when he heard the news.
He was overcome of emotion when he heard the news.
exercises.answer: He was overcome with emotion when he heard the news.
exercises.example_sentence: He was overcome with emotion when he heard the news.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with a double comparative.
exercises.answer: The harder you work the more likely you are to succeed
exercises.example_sentence: The harder you work, the more likely you are to succeed.

exercises.question: Match the C1 prefixes to their appropriate base words.
exercises.example_sentence: It is important not to overestimate the impact of the new law.

exercises.question: Pronounce the transition: 'On the flip side, there are several disadvantages to consider.'
exercises.answer: On the flip side, there are several disadvantages to consider.
exercises.example_sentence: On the flip side, there are several disadvantages to consider.

exercises.question: The decision was made ___ accordance with the new safety regulations.
exercises.answer: in
exercises.example_sentence: The decision was made in accordance with the new safety regulations.

exercises.question: Which of these expresses a strong possibility using 'likelihood'?
options: There is every likelihood that the plan will succeed.
There is each likelihood that the plan will succeed.
There is all likelihood that the plan will succeed.
exercises.answer: There is every likelihood that the plan will succeed.
exercises.example_sentence: There is every likelihood that the plan will succeed.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a necessary action.
exercises.answer: It is incumbent upon us to protect the environment
exercises.example_sentence: It is incumbent upon us to protect the environment.

exercises.question: Match the C1 connectors to their synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: The economy is struggling; moreover, unemployment is rising.

exercises.question: Pronounce the following for flow: 'Suffice it to say, the results were mixed.'
exercises.answer: Suffice it to say, the results were mixed.
exercises.example_sentence: Suffice it to say, the results were mixed.

exercises.question: The board has expressed its ___ at the lack of progress in the negotiations.
exercises.answer: displeasure
exercises.hint: Nominalization: Use the noun form for a formal tone
exercises.example_sentence: The board has expressed its displeasure at the lack of progress.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses an inverted conditional to express a past regret?
options: Had I known about the schedule change, I would have arrived earlier.
If I had known about the schedule change, I would arrive earlier.
Had I known about the schedule change, I would arrive earlier.
exercises.answer: Had I known about the schedule change, I would have arrived earlier.
exercises.hint: Inverted third conditional: Had + subject + past participle ... would have + past participle
exercises.example_sentence: Had I known about the schedule change, I would have arrived earlier.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a necessary condition.
exercises.answer: Only on receipt of the payment will the goods be dispatched
exercises.example_sentence: Only on receipt of the payment will the goods be dispatched.

exercises.question: Match the C1 verbs with their nominalized (noun) equivalents for formal writing.
exercises.hint: Nominalization makes writing more objective and formal
exercises.example_sentence: Strict compliance with the law is required.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal concession: 'Much as I respect his talent, I cannot agree with his methods.'
exercises.answer: Much as I respect his talent, I cannot agree with his methods.
exercises.example_sentence: Much as I respect his talent, I cannot agree with his methods.

exercises.question: The decision was made ___ the understanding that the budget would be increased.
exercises.answer: on
exercises.example_sentence: The decision was made on the understanding that the budget would be increased.

exercises.question: Select the correct way to express an action that is just about to happen.
options: The plane is on the verge of taking off.
The plane is on the point to take off.
The plane is at the verge of taking off.
exercises.answer: The plane is on the verge of taking off.
exercises.example_sentence: The plane is on the verge of taking off.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using 'Were' for a hypothetical present.
exercises.answer: Were it not for his help I would be completely lost
exercises.example_sentence: Were it not for his help, I would be completely lost.

exercises.question: Match the C1 adverbs with their subtle shades of meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: It will indubitably lead to a better outcome.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic inversion: 'Rarely have I seen such a brilliant performance.'
exercises.answer: Rarely have I seen such a brilliant performance.
exercises.example_sentence: Rarely have I seen such a brilliant performance.

exercises.question: The company’s growth is ___ to its investment in research and development.
exercises.answer: attributable
exercises.example_sentence: The company’s growth is attributable to its investment in R&D.

exercises.question: Choose the correct formal prepositional phrase for 'considering'.
options: In light of the recent findings, we must revise our strategy.
On light of the recent findings, we must revise our strategy.
At light of the recent findings, we must revise our strategy.
exercises.answer: In light of the recent findings, we must revise our strategy.
exercises.example_sentence: In light of the recent findings, we must revise our strategy.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a past probability.
exercises.answer: The document must have been misplaced during the move
exercises.hint: Subject + must have been + past participle
exercises.example_sentence: The document must have been misplaced during the move.

exercises.question: Match the formal phrasal verbs with their standard meanings.
exercises.hint: Common in business and formal contexts
exercises.example_sentence: We need to draw up a new contract.

exercises.question: Pronounce the conditional inversion: 'Should you require further information, please ask.'
exercises.answer: Should you require further information, please ask.
exercises.example_sentence: Should you require further information, please ask.

exercises.question: The negotiations are currently ___ a standstill.
exercises.answer: at
exercises.example_sentence: The negotiations are currently at a standstill.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'by no means' for negation.
options: This is by no means an easy task.
This is by no means a easy task.
This is by no means the easy task.
exercises.answer: This is by no means an easy task.
exercises.hint: 'By no means' acts as 'not at all'
exercises.example_sentence: This is by no means an easy task.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing the scale of a problem.
exercises.answer: The sheer number of applications was overwhelming
exercises.example_sentence: The sheer number of applications was overwhelming.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level idioms to their functions in a conversation.

pairs.left: To cut a long story short

exercises.hint: Idioms for professional and social contexts
exercises.example_sentence: We need to make sure everyone is on the same page.

exercises.question: Pronounce the finality: 'Needless to say, the project was abandoned.'
exercises.answer: Needless to say, the project was abandoned.
exercises.example_sentence: Needless to say, the project was abandoned.

exercises.question: It was only ___ he reached the airport that he realized he had forgotten his passport.
exercises.answer: when
exercises.hint: Cleft structure: 'It was only when... that...'
exercises.example_sentence: It was only when he reached the airport that he realized he had forgotten his passport.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly emphasizes the action using a 'What-cleft'?
options: What the company needs is a complete overhaul of its system.
What the company needs it is a complete overhaul of its system.
What the company needs was it a complete overhaul of its system.
exercises.answer: What the company needs is a complete overhaul of its system.
exercises.hint: Structure: What + subject + verb + is/was + [emphasized part]
exercises.example_sentence: What the company needs is a complete overhaul of its system.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a significant obstacle.
exercises.answer: The sudden withdrawal of funding was a major setback for us
exercises.example_sentence: The sudden withdrawal of funding was a major setback for us.

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verbs with their single-word C1 formal equivalents.
exercises.hint: Formal writing often replaces phrasal verbs with Latinate verbs
exercises.example_sentence: You need to substantiate your claims with evidence.

exercises.question: Pronounce the correlative: 'The more sophisticated the technology, the more vulnerable it becomes.'
exercises.answer: The more sophisticated the technology, the more vulnerable it becomes.
exercises.example_sentence: The more sophisticated the technology, the more vulnerable it becomes.

exercises.question: ___ only was the hotel expensive, but it was also quite dirty.
exercises.answer: Not
exercises.example_sentence: Not only was the hotel expensive, but it was also quite dirty.

exercises.question: Choose the correct preposition to complete the formal expression.
options: There is no justification for such a drastic measure.
There is no justification of such a drastic measure.
There is no justification by such a drastic measure.
exercises.answer: There is no justification for such a drastic measure.
exercises.example_sentence: There is no justification for such a drastic measure.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a past habitual action using 'would'.
exercises.answer: Every morning he would sit on the porch and watch the sunrise
exercises.example_sentence: Every morning he would sit on the porch and watch the sunrise.

exercises.question: Match the C1 nouns derived from phrasal verbs with their meanings.
exercises.hint: These nouns are common in business reports
exercises.example_sentence: We are still waiting for the final outcomes of the trial.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic cleft: 'It was my sister who eventually convinced me to go.'
exercises.answer: It was my sister who eventually convinced me to go.
exercises.example_sentence: It was my sister who eventually convinced me to go.

exercises.question: Hardly had the play begun ___ someone's phone started ringing.
exercises.answer: when
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had the play begun when someone's phone started ringing.

exercises.question: Identify the correct structure to express a hypothetical past preference.
options: I would rather have gone to the cinema than stayed at home.
I would rather had gone to the cinema than stayed at home.
I would rather to have gone to the cinema than stayed at home.
exercises.answer: I would rather have gone to the cinema than stayed at home.
exercises.hint: Would rather + perfect infinitive (have + past participle)
exercises.example_sentence: I would rather have gone to the cinema than stayed at home.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about an unavoidable change.
exercises.answer: The advent of the internet brought about a paradigm shift
exercises.example_sentence: The advent of the internet brought about a paradigm shift.

exercises.question: Match the logical connectors with their synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: You can go, provided that you finish your chores.

exercises.question: Pronounce the participle clause: 'Having been warned of the risks, he still decided to proceed.'
exercises.answer: Having been warned of the risks, he still decided to proceed.
exercises.example_sentence: Having been warned of the risks, he still decided to proceed.

exercises.question: The evidence is ___ insufficient to support the prosecution's claims.
exercises.answer: wholly
exercises.example_sentence: The evidence is wholly insufficient to support the claims.

exercises.question: Select the correct way to express 'no matter what happens'.
options: Come what may, we will stand by our decision.
May what come, we will stand by our decision.
What come may, we will stand by our decision.
exercises.answer: Come what may, we will stand by our decision.
exercises.hint: Fixed idiomatic phrase for future uncertainty
exercises.example_sentence: Come what may, we will stand by our decision.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing the scale of a task.
exercises.answer: The magnitude of the challenge cannot be underestimated
exercises.example_sentence: The magnitude of the challenge cannot be underestimated.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level verbs to their common objects.
exercises.example_sentence: He tried to exert influence over the committee's decision.

exercises.question: Pronounce the finality: 'Suffice it to say, the project was a resounding success.'
exercises.answer: Suffice it to say, the project was a resounding success.
exercises.example_sentence: Suffice it to say, the project was a resounding success.

exercises.question: ___ that you were offered the position, would you be prepared to relocate?
exercises.answer: Supposing
exercises.hint: Hypothetical question: 'Supposing' is used to ask about an imaginary situation
exercises.example_sentence: Supposing that you were offered the position, would you relocate?

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence using 'with a view to'.
options: The company is restructuring with a view to improving efficiency.
The company is restructuring with a view to improve efficiency.
The company is restructuring with a view for improving efficiency.
exercises.answer: The company is restructuring with a view to improving efficiency.
exercises.example_sentence: The company is restructuring with a view to improving efficiency.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a formal condition for an emergency.
exercises.answer: In the event of a fire please exit the building immediately
exercises.example_sentence: In the event of a fire, please exit the building immediately.

exercises.question: Match the C1 business metaphors with their literal meanings.

pairs.right: To do something poorly to save money

exercises.hint: These terms are standard in corporate environments
exercises.example_sentence: We cannot afford to cut corners when it comes to safety.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal hypothesis: 'Imagine if we had invested in that startup five years ago.'
exercises.answer: Imagine if we had invested in that startup five years ago.
exercises.example_sentence: Imagine if we had invested in that startup five years ago.

exercises.question: The evidence was ___ inconsistent with the witness's testimony.
exercises.answer: glaringly
exercises.example_sentence: The evidence was glaringly inconsistent with the testimony.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'lest' for formal precaution.
options: He stayed quiet lest he should wake the baby.
He stayed quiet lest he wouldn't wake the baby.
He stayed quiet lest he wakes the baby.
exercises.answer: He stayed quiet lest he should wake the baby.
exercises.hint: Lest + subject + should + base verb (meaning 'to avoid the risk of')
exercises.example_sentence: He stayed quiet lest he should wake the baby.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a necessary standard.
exercises.answer: Your performance is not yet up to the required standard
exercises.example_sentence: Your performance is not yet up to the required standard.

exercises.question: Match the C1 intensifiers with their typical adjectives.
exercises.example_sentence: It is virtually impossible to finish this by tomorrow.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic result: 'So severe was the storm that all flights were cancelled.'
exercises.answer: So severe was the storm that all flights were cancelled.
exercises.example_sentence: So severe was the storm that all flights were cancelled.

exercises.question: I'd rather you ___ the news to the staff yourself.
exercises.answer: broke
exercises.hint: Preference: 'I'd rather + subject + past simple' for the present/future
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather you broke the news to the staff yourself.

exercises.question: Choose the most appropriate preposition to describe an influence.
options: The internet has had a profound impact on how we communicate.
The internet has had a profound impact at how we communicate.
The internet has had a profound impact in how we communicate.
exercises.answer: The internet has had a profound impact on how we communicate.
exercises.example_sentence: The internet has had a profound impact on how we communicate.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing regret.
exercises.answer: I wish I had taken the time to listen to her advice
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I had taken the time to listen to her advice.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level verbs to their definitions.
exercises.hint: Focus on verbs describing management and influence
exercises.example_sentence: The scandal has begun to undermine public trust.

exercises.question: Pronounce the transition: 'By the same token, we must also consider the costs.'
exercises.answer: By the same token, we must also consider the costs.
exercises.example_sentence: By the same token, we must also consider the costs.

exercises.question: The project is currently ___ schedule due to technical difficulties.
exercises.answer: behind
exercises.example_sentence: The project is currently behind schedule.

exercises.question: Select the correct way to express an action despite something.
options: In spite of the rain, the match went ahead as planned.
In spite the rain, the match went ahead as planned.
In spite of the rain, the match was gone ahead as planned.
exercises.answer: In spite of the rain, the match went ahead as planned.
exercises.example_sentence: In spite of the rain, the match went ahead as planned.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a widespread opinion.
exercises.answer: It is commonly held that education is the key to success
exercises.example_sentence: It is commonly held that education is the key to success.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words to their antonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: The plan was concise and easy to understand.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Broadly speaking, the results support our hypothesis.'
exercises.answer: Broadly speaking, the results support our hypothesis.
exercises.example_sentence: Broadly speaking, the results support our hypothesis.

exercises.question: The investigation was launched ___ the behest of the Prime Minister.
exercises.answer: at
exercises.hint: Fixed phrase: 'at the behest of' (because of someone's request/order)
exercises.example_sentence: The investigation was launched at the behest of the Prime Minister.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence that uses 'inference' properly.
options: Based on the data, the only logical inference is that the market is cooling.
Based on the data, the only logical implication is that the market is cooling.
Based on the data, the only logical imply is that the market is cooling.
exercises.answer: Based on the data, the only logical inference is that the market is cooling.
exercises.hint: An 'inference' is a conclusion reached through evidence/reasoning
exercises.example_sentence: Based on the data, the only logical inference is that the market is cooling.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a consequence.
exercises.answer: New safety measures were introduced in the wake of the accident
exercises.example_sentence: New safety measures were introduced in the wake of the accident.

exercises.question: Match the C1 discourse markers with their specific functions.
exercises.hint: Focus on the logical bridge these markers create
exercises.example_sentence: I don't like his style; for that matter, I don't like his attitude either.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal dismissal: 'That is entirely beside the point in this discussion.'
exercises.answer: That is entirely beside the point in this discussion.
exercises.example_sentence: That is entirely beside the point in this discussion.

exercises.question: The company’s survival is ___ a knife-edge.
exercises.answer: on
exercises.hint: Idiom: 'on a knife-edge' (in a very uncertain or dangerous situation)
exercises.example_sentence: The company’s survival is on a knife-edge.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'scarcely' for inversion?
options: Scarcely had the news been announced when the stock price plummeted.
Scarcely the news had been announced when the stock price plummeted.
Scarcely had the news been announced than the stock price plummeted.
exercises.answer: Scarcely had the news been announced when the stock price plummeted.
exercises.example_sentence: Scarcely had the news been announced when the stock price plummeted.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence expressing a reluctant admission.
exercises.answer: Admittedly the initial results were somewhat disappointing
exercises.example_sentence: Admittedly, the initial results were somewhat disappointing.

exercises.question: Match the advanced verbs with their legal/formal objects.
exercises.hint: These collocations are common in official documents
exercises.example_sentence: The committee decided to adjourn the meeting until tomorrow.

exercises.question: Pronounce the transition: 'Conversely, proponents argue that the tax will stimulate growth.'
exercises.answer: Conversely, proponents argue that the tax will stimulate growth.
exercises.example_sentence: Conversely, proponents argue that the tax will stimulate growth.

exercises.question: It is ___ to see how the two events could be unrelated.
exercises.answer: difficult
exercises.example_sentence: It is difficult to see how the two events could be unrelated.

exercises.question: Identify the correct formal way to express 'about'.
options: With regard to your application, we require more information.
With regard of your application, we require more information.
With regards for your application, we require more information.
exercises.answer: With regard to your application, we require more information.
exercises.example_sentence: With regard to your application, we require more information.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a necessary condition.
exercises.answer: The success of the mission hinges on accurate intelligence
exercises.example_sentence: The success of the mission hinges on accurate intelligence.

exercises.question: Match the C1 adjectives to their precise formal meanings.

pairs.right: Open to more than one interpretation

exercises.example_sentence: The project was delayed by an inordinate amount of paperwork.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic negation: 'In no way does this imply that we are giving up.'
exercises.answer: In no way does this imply that we are giving up.
exercises.example_sentence: In no way does this imply that we are giving up.

exercises.question: The decision was made ___ consultation with the local community.
exercises.answer: after
exercises.hint: Sequence of events: Preparation happened before the decision
exercises.example_sentence: The decision was made after consultation with the local community.

exercises.question: Choose the correct preposition to complete the idiomatic phrase.
options: The proposal was rejected out of hand.
The proposal was rejected by of hand.
The proposal was rejected in of hand.
exercises.answer: The proposal was rejected out of hand.
exercises.example_sentence: The proposal was rejected out of hand.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using a participle clause.
exercises.answer: Faced with mounting debts the company declared bankruptcy
exercises.example_sentence: Faced with mounting debts, the company declared bankruptcy.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words with their common formal opposites.
exercises.example_sentence: The difference in cost was negligible.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Paradoxically, the more we save, the less the economy grows.'
exercises.answer: Paradoxically, the more we save, the less the economy grows.
exercises.example_sentence: Paradoxically, the more we save, the less the economy grows.

exercises.question: The candidate's argument was ___ on the assumption that taxes would remain stable.
exercises.answer: predicated
exercises.hint: Formal verb: 'to be predicated on' means to be based on or founded on.
exercises.example_sentence: The candidate's argument was predicated on the assumption that taxes would remain stable.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence using 'lest' for formal precaution.
options: We must keep the information confidential lest it should fall into the wrong hands.
We must keep the information confidential lest it wouldn't fall into the wrong hands.
We must keep the information confidential lest it mightn't fall into the wrong hands.
exercises.answer: We must keep the information confidential lest it should fall into the wrong hands.
exercises.hint: Lest + subject + should + base verb expresses 'to prevent the risk of'.
exercises.example_sentence: We must keep the information confidential lest it should fall into the wrong hands.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a rare achievement.
exercises.answer: Seldom has a rookie demonstrated such composure under pressure
exercises.hint: Start with 'Seldom' to trigger the inversion.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom has a rookie demonstrated such composure under pressure.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level verbs to their formal synonyms.
exercises.hint: Focus on high-level academic and legal synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: The witness was able to corroborate the suspect's alibi.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal demand: 'It is vital that the committee reach a consensus by Friday.'
exercises.answer: It is vital that the committee reach a consensus by Friday.
exercises.hint: Stress 'vital' and 'consensus'. Note the use of the subjunctive 'reach'.
exercises.example_sentence: It is vital that the committee reach a consensus by Friday.

exercises.question: The plan was approved ___ the understanding that the budget would not be exceeded.
exercises.answer: on
exercises.hint: Fixed phrase: 'on the understanding that' (as long as).
exercises.example_sentence: The plan was approved on the understanding that the budget would not be exceeded.

exercises.question: Identify the correct use of 'no sooner' for chronological events.
options: No sooner had he left the building than it began to pour with rain.
No sooner he had left the building than it began to pour with rain.
No sooner had he left the building when it began to pour with rain.
exercises.answer: No sooner had he left the building than it began to pour with rain.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had he left the building than it began to pour with rain.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a necessary consequence.
exercises.answer: The prolonged drought will inevitably result in higher food prices
exercises.hint: The adverb 'inevitably' should precede the main verb 'result'.
exercises.example_sentence: The prolonged drought will inevitably result in higher food prices.

exercises.question: Match the C1 prefixes to their sophisticated definitions.
exercises.hint: Greek and Latin roots used in academic English.
exercises.example_sentence: The report was dismissed as a pseudo-scientific study.

exercises.question: Pronounce the complex contrast: 'While the initial results were promising, subsequent trials proved inconclusive.'
exercises.answer: While the initial results were promising, subsequent trials proved inconclusive.
exercises.example_sentence: While the initial results were promising, subsequent trials proved inconclusive.

exercises.question: The decision was made ___ accordance with the latest safety protocols.
exercises.answer: in
exercises.hint: Fixed phrase: 'in accordance with' (following the rules).
exercises.example_sentence: The decision was made in accordance with the latest safety protocols.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence using an 'It-cleft' for focus.
options: It was his lack of punctuality that cost him the promotion.
It was his lack of punctuality cost him the promotion.
It was his lack of punctuality which it cost him the promotion.
exercises.answer: It was his lack of punctuality that cost him the promotion.
exercises.example_sentence: It was his lack of punctuality that cost him the promotion.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a past habitual action.
exercises.answer: Throughout his childhood he would frequently visit the local library
exercises.hint: Use 'would' to describe a past habit.
exercises.example_sentence: Throughout his childhood, he would frequently visit the local library.

exercises.question: Match the C1 idioms to their appropriate contexts.

pairs.right: In a similar way or style

exercises.hint: Focus on the idiomatic meaning in professional settings.
exercises.example_sentence: Whether we should have hired him is now a moot point.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic negation: 'Under no circumstances should you leave the premises.'
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances should you leave the premises.
exercises.hint: Stress 'no' and 'leave'. Use the rising-falling intonation of a command.
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances should you leave the premises.

exercises.question: The manager ___ that the task be completed by the end of the day.
exercises.answer: stipulated
exercises.hint: Formal verb: to specify a requirement as part of an agreement.
exercises.example_sentence: The manager stipulated that the task be completed by the end of the day.

exercises.question: Select the correct formal prepositional phrase for 'considering'.
options: In light of the recent developments, we have decided to postpone.
On light of the recent developments, we have decided to postpone.
At light of the recent developments, we have decided to postpone.
exercises.answer: In light of the recent developments, we have decided to postpone.
exercises.hint: Fixed phrase: 'In light of' (taking something into account).
exercises.example_sentence: In light of the recent developments, we have decided to postpone.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using a participle clause.
exercises.answer: Having finished the report she submitted it to her supervisor
exercises.hint: Start with the perfect participle 'Having finished'.
exercises.example_sentence: Having finished the report, she submitted it to her supervisor.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words to their collocations.
exercises.example_sentence: The two issues are inextricably linked.

exercises.question: Pronounce the logical connector: 'Consequently, the board has decided to increase the dividend.'
exercises.answer: Consequently, the board has decided to increase the dividend.
exercises.example_sentence: Consequently, the board has decided to increase the dividend.

exercises.question: Only when the results were published ___ the scale of the error become apparent.
exercises.answer: did
exercises.hint: Inversion: Only when + clause + auxiliary + subject + verb
exercises.example_sentence: Only when the results were published did the scale of the error become apparent.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly expresses a past action that was done but was unnecessary?
options: I needn't have cooked so much food, as half the guests didn't show up.
I didn't need to cook so much food, so I only made a small salad.
I hadn't need to cook so much food, as nobody was hungry anyway.
exercises.answer: I needn't have cooked so much food, as half the guests didn't show up.
exercises.hint: 'Needn't have + past participle' means the action happened but wasn't necessary
exercises.example_sentence: I needn't have cooked so much food, as half the guests didn't show up.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a logical conclusion.
exercises.answer: There is every likelihood that the recession will deepen this quarter
exercises.example_sentence: There is every likelihood that the recession will deepen this quarter.

exercises.question: Match the C1 verbs to their formal definitions regarding change.
exercises.hint: Focus on the specific nature of the change
exercises.example_sentence: The price of gold tends to fluctuate on a daily basis.

exercises.question: Pronounce the critical modal: 'We might as well have stayed at home for all the good the meeting did.'
exercises.answer: We might as well have stayed at home for all the good the meeting did.
exercises.hint: Stress 'might as well' to show frustration
exercises.example_sentence: We might as well have stayed at home for all the good the meeting did.

exercises.question: The suspect’s story was ___ with holes, making it easy to disprove.
exercises.answer: riddled
exercises.hint: Idiom: 'riddled with' (containing many unpleasant things, e.g., errors or holes)
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect’s story was riddled with holes.

exercises.question: Select the correct formal way to describe something that is just about to happen.
options: The negotiations are on the point of breaking down.
The negotiations are on the point to break down.
The negotiations are at the point of breaking down.
exercises.answer: The negotiations are on the point of breaking down.
exercises.example_sentence: The negotiations are on the point of breaking down.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a hypothetical past.
exercises.answer: But for the timely intervention the outcome would have been fatal
exercises.hint: Start with 'But for' (meaning 'If it hadn't been for')
exercises.example_sentence: But for the timely intervention, the outcome would have been fatal.

exercises.question: Match the C1 prefixes to their meanings in professional contexts.
exercises.hint: Standard prefixes for corporate and academic roles
exercises.example_sentence: The counter-proposal was rejected by the board.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic inversion: 'Under no circumstances are employees allowed to smoke on site.'
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances are employees allowed to smoke on site.
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances are employees allowed to smoke on site.

exercises.question: He resigned ___ a cloud after the audit revealed several irregularities.
exercises.answer: under
exercises.hint: Idiom: 'under a cloud' (under suspicion or in disgrace)
exercises.example_sentence: He resigned under a cloud after the audit revealed irregularities.

exercises.question: Choose the correct preposition to describe a decrease.
options: There has been a sharp decline in the number of applicants.
There has been a sharp decline on the number of applicants.
There has been a sharp decline of the number of applicants.
exercises.answer: There has been a sharp decline in the number of applicants.
exercises.example_sentence: There has been a sharp decline in the number of applicants.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a recurring problem.
exercises.answer: The issue of funding is a perennial problem for the charity
exercises.example_sentence: The issue of funding is a perennial problem for the charity.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words to their sophisticated opposites.
exercises.hint: Focus on high-level antonyms for descriptions
exercises.example_sentence: The symptoms were manifest and easy to diagnose.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Broadly speaking, the results are in line with our expectations.'
exercises.answer: Broadly speaking, the results are in line with our expectations.
exercises.example_sentence: Broadly speaking, the results are in line with our expectations.

exercises.question: The new legislation is ___ to come into force next January.
exercises.answer: due
exercises.example_sentence: The new legislation is due to come into force next January.

exercises.question: Identify the correct formal way to describe a reason for something.
options: The success of the project was down to the team’s hard work.
The success of the project was along to the team’s hard work.
The success of the project was across to the team’s hard work.
exercises.answer: The success of the project was down to the team’s hard work.
exercises.hint: 'Be down to' is a common phrase for attribution in business/formal settings
exercises.example_sentence: The success of the project was down to the team’s hard work.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a future possibility.
exercises.answer: The new law could have far-reaching implications for small businesses
exercises.example_sentence: The new law could have far-reaching implications for small businesses.

exercises.question: Match the reporting verbs with the degree of certainty they imply.
exercises.example_sentence: The economist maintains that interest rates will stay low.

exercises.question: Pronounce the transition: 'In a nutshell, we need to cut costs by ten percent.'
exercises.answer: In a nutshell, we need to cut costs by ten percent.
exercises.example_sentence: In a nutshell, we need to cut costs by ten percent.

exercises.question: Little ___ he realize that his decision would change the course of history.
exercises.answer: did
exercises.hint: Negative inversion: 'Little' + auxiliary + subject + verb (base form).
exercises.example_sentence: Little did he realize that his decision would change the course of history.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses a nominalized structure for a formal report?
options: The sudden closure of the factory led to significant job losses.
The factory closed sudden and it led to significant job losses.
Because the factory closed sudden, significant job losses happened.
exercises.answer: The sudden closure of the factory led to significant job losses.
exercises.hint: Nominalization: Using 'The closure' (noun) instead of 'The factory closed' (verb) makes it more formal.
exercises.example_sentence: The sudden closure of the factory led to significant job losses.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about taking offense.
exercises.answer: The ambassador took exception to the remarks made by the journalist
exercises.hint: Phrase: 'to take exception to something' (to object or be offended).
exercises.example_sentence: The ambassador took exception to the remarks made by the journalist.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level verbs to their formal objects.
exercises.hint: Focus on legal and administrative collocations.
exercises.example_sentence: We must take immediate action to mitigate the risk of data loss.

exercises.question: Pronounce the formal concession: 'Be that as it may, we still need to address the underlying issue.'
exercises.answer: Be that as it may, we still need to address the underlying issue.
exercises.example_sentence: Be that as it may, we still need to address the underlying issue.

exercises.question: The company is ___ the brink of bankruptcy following the recent scandal.
exercises.answer: on
exercises.hint: Idiom: 'on the brink of' (very close to a significant/bad situation).
exercises.example_sentence: The company is on the brink of bankruptcy following the recent scandal.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence to express an unlikely hypothetical.
options: Were the government to raise taxes, there would be public outcry.
Were the government raised taxes, there would be public outcry.
If the government raises taxes, there would be public outcry.
exercises.answer: Were the government to raise taxes, there would be public outcry.
exercises.hint: Formal inversion: Were + subject + to-infinitive (hypothetical future).
exercises.example_sentence: Were the government to raise taxes, there would be public outcry.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a widespread problem.
exercises.answer: Corruption is said to be rife within the local government
exercises.hint: Use 'rife' to mean widespread or common (usually something bad).
exercises.example_sentence: Corruption is said to be rife within the local government.

exercises.question: Match the C1 discourse markers to their logical relationship.
exercises.hint: Focus on the function of the transition.
exercises.example_sentence: The plan was risky; accordingly, we proceeded with caution.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic inversion: 'Not only did they arrive late, but they also forgot the documents.'
exercises.answer: Not only did they arrive late, but they also forgot the documents.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only did they arrive late, but they also forgot the documents.

exercises.question: The witness's account of the event was ___ with contradictions.
exercises.answer: shot
exercises.hint: Idiom: 'shot through with' (filled with a particular quality). Note: 'riddled with' also works, but 'shot through' is a distinct C1 alternative.
exercises.example_sentence: The witness's account of the event was shot through with contradictions.

exercises.question: Identify the correct preposition for expressing high regard.
options: She is held in high esteem by her colleagues.
She is held with high esteem by her colleagues.
She is held at high esteem by her colleagues.
exercises.answer: She is held in high esteem by her colleagues.
exercises.hint: Fixed phrase: 'to hold someone in high esteem'.
exercises.example_sentence: She is held in high esteem by her colleagues.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a subtle change.
exercises.answer: There has been a subtle shift in the public mood
exercises.example_sentence: There has been a subtle shift in the public mood.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words to their sophisticated antonyms.
exercises.hint: Focus on descriptors for rules and quantity.
exercises.example_sentence: The safety regulations were dangerously lax.

exercises.question: Pronounce the transition: 'Conversely, many experts believe the opposite to be true.'
exercises.answer: Conversely, many experts believe the opposite to be true.
exercises.example_sentence: Conversely, many experts believe the opposite to be true.

exercises.question: In the ___ analysis, the decision comes down to cost.
exercises.answer: final
exercises.hint: Fixed discourse marker: 'In the final analysis' (ultimately).
exercises.example_sentence: In the final analysis, the decision comes down to cost.

exercises.question: Select the correct way to express an action done with a specific intent.
options: He spoke slowly so as to be understood by everyone.
He spoke slowly so as being understood by everyone.
He spoke slowly so to be understood by everyone.
exercises.answer: He spoke slowly so as to be understood by everyone.
exercises.example_sentence: He spoke slowly so as to be understood by everyone.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a necessary standard.
exercises.answer: We must ensure that all equipment is of the highest calibre
exercises.hint: Use 'calibre' to refer to quality or level of ability.
exercises.example_sentence: We must ensure that all equipment is of the highest calibre.

exercises.question: Match the C1 idioms to their metaphorical meanings.

pairs.right: To be exactly what is needed

exercises.hint: Focus on idioms common in professional evaluations.
exercises.example_sentence: His excuses cut no ice with the manager.

exercises.question: Pronounce the finality: 'Needless to say, the proposal was rejected out of hand.'
exercises.answer: Needless to say, the proposal was rejected out of hand.
exercises.example_sentence: Needless to say, the proposal was rejected out of hand.

exercises.question: ___ it not for the last-minute intervention, the company would have gone under.
exercises.answer: Were
exercises.hint: Hypothetical inversion: 'Were it not for...' refers to a present or general state affecting a past result.
exercises.example_sentence: Were it not for the last-minute intervention, the company would have gone under.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses an 'All-cleft' for emphasis?
options: All I did was suggest that we postpone the meeting.
All what I did was suggest that we postpone the meeting.
All that I did it was suggest that we postpone the meeting.
exercises.answer: All I did was suggest that we postpone the meeting.
exercises.hint: Cleft structure: All + subject + verb + is/was + [emphasized part].
exercises.example_sentence: All I did was suggest that we postpone the meeting.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence using a formal negative adverbial.
exercises.answer: On no account should the security codes be shared with third parties
exercises.example_sentence: On no account should the security codes be shared with third parties.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level verbs with their formal meanings in a debate.

pairs.right: Prove a statement to be wrong
Admit something is true after first denying it
Develop or present a theory in detail

exercises.hint: Focus on verbs used in academic or formal discussions.
exercises.example_sentence: I would like to reiterate my support for the new policy.

exercises.question: Pronounce the complex condition: 'Should any complications arise, please contact the lead investigator.'
exercises.answer: Should any complications arise, please contact the lead investigator.
exercises.example_sentence: Should any complications arise, please contact the lead investigator.

exercises.question: The evidence is ___ with the theory that the climate is warming rapidly.
exercises.answer: consistent
exercises.example_sentence: The evidence is consistent with the theory that the climate is warming rapidly.

exercises.question: Select the correct way to express an action despite difficulties.
options: In the face of adversity, the team remained resilient.
At the face of adversity, the team remained resilient.
With the face of adversity, the team remained resilient.
exercises.answer: In the face of adversity, the team remained resilient.
exercises.hint: Fixed phrase: 'In the face of' (when confronted with).
exercises.example_sentence: In the face of adversity, the team remained resilient.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a logical consequence.
exercises.answer: The failure of the pump resulted in the flooding of the entire basement
exercises.example_sentence: The failure of the pump resulted in the flooding of the entire basement.

exercises.question: Match the C1 prefixes to their sophisticated meanings.
exercises.hint: Latin roots for formal word formation.
exercises.example_sentence: The device experienced a critical malfunction during the test.

exercises.question: Pronounce the transition: 'In light of these findings, we must reconsider our approach.'
exercises.answer: In light of these findings, we must reconsider our approach.
exercises.example_sentence: In light of these findings, we must reconsider our approach.

exercises.question: The government's response was ___ as 'wholly inadequate' by the opposition.
exercises.answer: characterised
exercises.hint: Formal verb: 'to be characterised as' (to be described in a particular way).
exercises.example_sentence: The government's response was characterised as 'wholly inadequate'.

exercises.question: Choose the correct formal prepositional phrase for 'instead of'.
options: In lieu of a cash payment, we were offered store credit.
In place for a cash payment, we were offered store credit.
At lieu of a cash payment, we were offered store credit.
exercises.answer: In lieu of a cash payment, we were offered store credit.
exercises.example_sentence: In lieu of a cash payment, we were offered store credit.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a past occurrence using inversion.
exercises.answer: Hardly had the ceremony ended when the protests began
exercises.hint: Start with 'Hardly' to trigger the past perfect inversion.
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had the ceremony ended when the protests began.

exercises.question: Match the C1 words to their precise opposites.
exercises.example_sentence: The laws were considered archaic and in need of reform.

exercises.question: Pronounce the emphatic focus: 'It is the lack of transparency that is most concerning.'
exercises.answer: It is the lack of transparency that is most concerning.
exercises.example_sentence: It is the lack of transparency that is most concerning.

exercises.question: The success of the project is ___ on everyone’s full cooperation.
exercises.answer: contingent
exercises.hint: Formal phrase: 'be contingent on' (subject to/dependent on).
exercises.example_sentence: The success of the project is contingent on everyone’s full cooperation.

exercises.question: Identify the correct way to express an action following another.
options: Upon completion of the course, students receive a certificate.
At completion of the course, students receive a certificate.
With completion of the course, students receive a certificate.
exercises.answer: Upon completion of the course, students receive a certificate.
exercises.hint: Upon + noun phrase (formal alternative to 'When the course is completed').
exercises.example_sentence: Upon completion of the course, students receive a certificate.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence about a necessary standard.
exercises.answer: We must strive to uphold the integrity of the judicial system
exercises.hint: Use 'uphold' to mean maintain or support.
exercises.example_sentence: We must strive to uphold the integrity of the judicial system.

exercises.question: Match the C1 level idioms to their functions.
exercises.example_sentence: Much of the work happens behind the scenes.

exercises.question: Pronounce the finality: 'Suffice it to say, the matter has been resolved.'
exercises.answer: Suffice it to say, the matter has been resolved.
exercises.example_sentence: Suffice it to say, the matter has been resolved.
